Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Representation Theory, Combinatorics, and Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The award will support participation of primarily early-career researchers in the Workshop on Representation Theory, Combinatorics, and Geometry, and the Distinguished Lecture Series "Virginia Mathematics Lectures" which will take place on October 19-21 and 22-24, 2019, respectively, at the University of Virginia. The workshop will consist of talks by leading experts on connections between quantum groups, quiver varieties, and canonical bases, as well as short talks by early-career participants. Participants will be exposed to exciting new directions in representation theory, geometry, and combinatorics, and will gain fodder for future projects. The diversity of mathematical researchers and areas represented at the workshop will foster new collaborations and new research projects.

In more detail, Springer resolutions of nilpotent cones of semisimple Lie algebras provide a fertile ground for geometric representation theory. Maulik and Okounkov introduced a notion of stable envelope in the framework of symplectic resolutions (with Springer resolutions and quiver varieties as most important examples), and used it to provide a first geometric construction of R-matrices and a different construction of Yangians using the equivariant cohomology in a wide context. Their construction is intimately related to quantum cohomology of the symplectic resolutions. These subjects have played an important role in several areas of modern mathematics. Some of the most recent research directions (such as i-quiver varieties) have emerged only in the last year or so, and are currently aligning with Maulik-Okounkov's theory. The events at University of Virginia will provide a timely platform for exchange of emerging new ideas that will facilitate their further development. The website of the workshop is http://math.virginia.edu/ims/workshop-fall-2018/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Department of Mathematics and the Institute of Mathematical Science at the University of Virginia held a workshop on Representation Theory, Combinatorics, and Geometry on October 19-21, 2018, followed by the Virginia Mathematics Lecture series by the Fields medalist Andrei Okounkov (Columbia University) on 22-24, 2018. The workshop was organized by Leonid Petrov (PI), Jennifer Morse (co-PI), Weiqiang Wang (co-PI), all from Department of Mathematics at University of Virginia. The workshop had 12 plenary talks, and was attended by 65 participants (this number includes the speakers). Some of the participants stayed for the lecture series by Okounkov. 

The workshop topics involved research directions within representation theory, combinatorics, and geometry which have emerged only in the last two years, and are currently aligning with existing theory of stable envelope and Yangians developed earlier by Maulik and Okounkov. This made the meeting a timely platform for exchange of emerging new ideas which helped facilitate their further development. Junior participants were encouraged to present short communications, and the organizers selected 9 talks (3 per day) which complemented the plenary talks. PDF slides of most of the plenary and contributed talks have been made available at the workshop website at https://math.virginia.edu/ims/workshop-fall-2018/. The strong learning component of the workshop is important for development of a new generation of researchers in representation theory, geometry, and combinatorics.

The $15,000 support from NSF was used to partially cover travel and lodging expenses for 28 participants, which included 20 graduate students, 12 women, and 4 members of other underrepresented groups.

Prior to the workshop, the organizers performed a number of concrete steps (outlined in the final project report) towards attracting a diverse audience of junior researchers and graduate students, in particular junior women mathematicians. The organizers selected participants who received funding based on their research record (for postdocs and junior faculty) and/or recommendation letter (for graduate students). Recruitment and selection of participants emphasized participation of women mathematicians, members of other underrepresented groups, and junior researchers.
